has only recently been significantly transcended; see two numbers
title: Chapter 1. A good deal of recent discussion has considered the extent of change in the post-Roman period. In a number of works by Peter Brown, the fall of the Roman Empire is scarcely noticeable: see in particular The World of Late Antiquity
and The Rise of Western Christendom

I have suggested elements of a response to the second of these books in Journal of Religious History 29, 2005, 67–76. A contrary argument is spelt out in the title of a book by Bryan Ward-Perkins: The Fall of Rome and the End of Civilization

Their approaches rely on different bodies of evidence, and indirectly reflect different views of the kinds of things that are important in human affairs. Another significantly titled book arguing for decline rather than transformation is that of
The Decline and Fall of the Roman City
Those seeking visual evidence will find plenty in Leslie Webster and Michelle Brown, The Transformation of the Roman World, AD 400–900

Europe after Rome, Oxford, 2005, is strong on cultural history. The concept of decline is difficult; population certainly fell during late antiquity, but need this be interpreted as evidence for decline? Averil Cameron, The Mediterranean World in Late Antiquity AD 395–600
is thought-provoking; the older work of A
remains an immensely suggestive source of information, while on the concept of the Mediterranean V
